<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Philadelphia skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Philadelphia</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
<b>Philadelphia</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>) is the largest city in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_(U.S._state)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth (U.S. state) (page does not exist)">Commonwealth</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, the second largest city on the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">East Coast of the United States</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population" title="List of United States cities by population">fifth-most-populous city</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-largest_cities_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-largest_cities-1">[1]</a></sup> It is located in the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">Northeastern United States</a> at the confluence of the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware</a> and <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_River" title="Schuylkill River">Schuylkill</a> rivers, and it is the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania">only consolidated city-county</a> in Pennsylvania. As of the <span class="nowrap"><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 Census</a></span>, the city had a population of 1,526,006,<sup id="cite_ref-population_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-population-2">[2]</a></sup> growing to 1,547,607 in 2012 by Census estimates.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Philadelphia is the economic and cultural center of the <span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Delaware_Valley" title="Delaware Valley">Delaware Valley</a></span>, home to over 6&#160;million people and the country's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Metropolitan_Statistical_Areas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Metropolitan Statistical Areas (page does not exist)">sixth-largest metropolitan area</a>. Within the Delaware Valley, the Philadelphia metropolitan division consists of five counties in Pennsylvania and has a population of 4,008,994. Popular nicknames for Philadelphia are <i>Philly</i> and <i>The City of Brotherly Love</i>, the latter of which comes from the literal meaning of the city's name in Greek (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-el&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-el (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-el</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-el&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-el (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-el</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-el&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-el (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-el</a>) "brotherly love", compounded from <i>philos</i> (φίλος) "loving", and <i>adelphos</i> (ἀδελφός)  "brother").<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1682, <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Penn (page does not exist)">William Penn</a> founded the city to serve as capital of <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Pennsylvania" title="Province of Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania Colony</a>. By the 1750s, Philadelphia had surpassed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boston (page does not exist)">Boston</a> to become the largest city and busiest port in <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British America (page does not exist)">British America</a>, and second in the British Empire, behind <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, Philadelphia played an instrumental role as a meeting place for the <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">Founding Fathers of the United States</a>, who signed the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a> in 1776 and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">Constitution</a> in 1787. Philadelphia was one of the nation's <a href="/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_the_United_States" title="List of capitals in the United States">capitals</a> during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">Revolutionary War</a>, and the city served as the temporary U.S. capital while <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, was under construction. During the 19th century, Philadelphia became a major industrial center and railroad hub that grew from an influx of European immigrants. It became a prime destination for African Americans during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a> and surpassed two million occupants by 1950.
</p><p>The city is the center of economic activity in <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, and is home to the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Stock_Exchange" title="Philadelphia Stock Exchange">Philadelphia Stock Exchange</a> and several <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies.
</p><p>Philadelphia is known for its arts and culture. The <a href="/wiki/Cheesesteak" title="Cheesesteak">cheesesteak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pretzel" title="Pretzel">soft pretzel</a> are emblematic of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuisine_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuisine of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Philadelphia cuisine</a>, which is shaped by the city's ethnic mix. The city has more outdoor sculptures and murals than any other American city,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> and Philadelphia's <a href="/wiki/Fairmount_Park" title="Fairmount Park">Fairmount Park</a> is the largest landscaped urban park in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Philadelphia_profile_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philadelphia_profile-9">[9]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">Gentrification</a> of Philadelphia's neighborhoods continues into the 21st century and the city has reversed its decades-long trend of population loss.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Penn_with_Indians_by_Benjamin_West.jpg" title="File:Treaty of Penn with Indians by Benjamin West.jpg">File:Treaty of Penn with Indians by Benjamin West.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Penn%27s_Treaty_with_the_Indians&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Penn's Treaty with the Indians (page does not exist)">Penn's Treaty with the Indians</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_West" title="Benjamin West">Benjamin West</a></div></div></div>
<p>Before Europeans arrived, the Philadelphia area was home to the <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">Lenape (Delaware)</a> <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Indians</a> in the village of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shackamaxon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shackamaxon (page does not exist)">Shackamaxon</a>.
Europeans came to the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Valley" title="Delaware Valley">Delaware Valley</a> in the early 17th century, with the first settlements founded by the Dutch, who in 1623 built <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Nassau_(South_River)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Nassau (South River) (page does not exist)">Fort Nassau</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware River</a> opposite the <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_River" title="Schuylkill River">Schuylkill River</a> in what is now <a href="/wiki/Brooklawn,_New_Jersey" title="Brooklawn, New Jersey">Brooklawn, New Jersey</a>. The Dutch considered the entire Delaware River valley to be part of their <a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a> colony. In 1638, Swedish settlers led by renegade Dutch established the colony of <a href="/wiki/New_Sweden" title="New Sweden">New Sweden</a> at <a href="/wiki/Fort_Christina" title="Fort Christina">Fort Christina</a> (present day Wilmington, Delaware) and quickly spread out in the valley. In 1644, <a href="/wiki/New_Sweden" title="New Sweden">New Sweden</a> supported the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Susquehannocks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Susquehannocks (page does not exist)">Susquehannocks</a> in their military defeat of the English colony of Maryland. In 1648, the Dutch built <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Beversreede&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Beversreede (page does not exist)">Fort Beversreede</a> on the west bank of the Delaware, south of the Schuylkill near the present-day <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eastwick,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eastwick, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Eastwick</a> section of Philadelphia, to reassert their dominion over the area. The Swedes responded by building <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Nya_Korsholm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Nya Korsholm (page does not exist)">Fort Nya Korsholm</a>, named New Korsholm after a town that is now in Finland. In 1655, a Dutch military campaign led by New Netherland Director-General <a href="/wiki/Peter_Stuyvesant" title="Peter Stuyvesant">Peter Stuyvesant</a> took control of the Swedish colony, ending its claim to independence, although the Swedish and Finnish settlers continued to have their own militia, religion, and court, and to enjoy substantial autonomy under the Dutch. The English conquered the New Netherland colony in 1664, but the situation did not really change until 1682, when the area was included in <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Penn (page does not exist)">William Penn</a>'s charter for Pennsylvania.
</p><p>In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> granted <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Penn (page does not exist)">William Penn</a> a <a href="/wiki/Charter" title="Charter">charter</a> for what would become the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Pennsylvania" title="Province of Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania colony</a>. Despite the royal charter, Penn bought the land from the local Lenape to be on good terms with the Native Americans and ensure peace for his colony.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Legend" title="Legend">legend</a> Penn made a treaty of friendship with Lenape chief <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tamanend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tamanend (page does not exist)">Tammany</a> under an elm tree at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shackamaxon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shackamaxon (page does not exist)">Shackamaxon</a>, in what is now the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fishtown,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fishtown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Fishtown section</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> Penn named the city Philadelphia, which is <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> for brotherly love (from <i>philos</i>, "love" or "friendship", and <i>adelphos</i>, "brother"). As a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Religious_Society_of_Friends&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Religious Society of Friends (page does not exist)">Quaker</a>, Penn had experienced religious persecution and wanted his colony to be a place where anyone could worship freely. This tolerance, far more than afforded by most other colonies, led to better relations with the local Native tribes and fostered Philadelphia's rapid growth into America's most important city.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
Penn planned a city on the Delaware River to serve as a port and place for government. Hoping that Philadelphia would become more like an English rural town instead of a city, Penn laid out roads on a <a href="/wiki/Grid_plan" title="Grid plan">grid plan</a> to keep houses and businesses spread far apart, with areas for gardens and orchards. The city's inhabitants did not follow Penn's plans, as they crowded by the Delaware River, the port, and subdivided and resold their lots.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Before Penn left Philadelphia for the last time, he issued the Charter of 1701 establishing it as a city. It became an important trading center, poor at first, but with tolerable living conditions by the 1750s. <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, a leading citizen, helped improve city services and founded new ones, such as fire protection, a library, and one of the American colonies' first hospitals.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_Franklin_by_Jean-Baptiste_Greuze.jpg" title="File:Benjamin Franklin by Jean-Baptiste Greuze.jpg">File:Benjamin Franklin by Jean-Baptiste Greuze.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, 1777</div></div></div>
<p>A number of important philosophical societies were formed, which were centers of the city's intellectual life: the Philadelphia Society for Promoting Agriculture (1785), the Pennsylvania Society for the Encouragement of Manufactures and the Useful Arts (1787), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Natural_Sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy of Natural Sciences (page does not exist)">Academy of Natural Sciences</a> (1812), and the <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Institute" title="Franklin Institute">Franklin Institute</a> (1824).<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> These worked to develop and finance new industries and attract skilled and knowledgeable immigrants from Europe.
</p><p>Philadelphia's importance and central location in the colonies made it a natural center for <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">America's revolutionaries</a>. The city hosted the <a href="/wiki/First_Continental_Congress" title="First Continental Congress">First Continental Congress</a> before the war; the <a href="/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress" title="Second Continental Congress">Second Continental Congress</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WDL1_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WDL1-15">[15]</a></sup> which signed the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">United States Declaration of Independence</a>, during the war; and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Convention&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Convention (page does not exist)">Constitutional Convention</a> (1787) after the war. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_campaign&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia campaign (page does not exist)">Several battles</a> were fought in and near Philadelphia as well.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg" title="File:PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg">File:PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=President%27s_House_(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President's House (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania) (page does not exist)">President's House</a>, Philadelphia. This mansion at 6th &amp; Market Streets served as the presidential mansion of George Washington and John Adams, 1790–1800.</div></div></div>
<p>Philadelphia served as the temporary capital of the United States, 1790–1800, while the <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Federal City</a> was under construction in the <a href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia" title="District of Columbia" class="mw-redirect">District of Columbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> In 1793, the largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow_Fever_Epidemic_of_1793&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1793 (page does not exist)">yellow fever epidemics</a> in U.S. history killed at least 4,000 and up to 5,000 people in Philadelphia, roughly 10% of the city's population.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>The state government left Philadelphia in 1799, and the federal government was moved to Washington, DC in 1800 with completion of the White House and Capitol.  The city remained the young nation's largest with a population of nearly 50,000 at the turn of the 19th century; it was a financial and cultural center. Before 1800, its free black community founded the <a href="/wiki/African_Methodist_Episcopal_Church" title="African Methodist Episcopal Church">African Methodist Episcopal Church</a> (AME), the first independent black denomination in the country, and the first black Episcopal Church. The free black community also established many schools for its children, with the help of Quakers.  New York City soon surpassed Philadelphia in population, but with the construction of roads, <a href="/wiki/Canal" title="Canal">canals</a>, and railroads, Philadelphia became the first major industrial city in the United States.
</p><p>Throughout the 19th century, Philadelphia had a variety of industries and businesses, the largest being textiles. Major corporations in the 19th and early 20th centuries included the <a href="/wiki/Baldwin_Locomotive_Works" title="Baldwin Locomotive Works">Baldwin Locomotive Works</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Cramp_and_Sons&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Cramp and Sons (page does not exist)">William Cramp and Sons Ship and Engine Building Company</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Railroad" title="Pennsylvania Railroad">Pennsylvania Railroad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Industry, along with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Centennial" title="United States Centennial" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Centennial</a>, was celebrated in 1876 with the <a href="/wiki/Centennial_Exposition" title="Centennial Exposition">Centennial Exposition</a>, the first official <a href="/wiki/World%27s_fair" title="World's fair">World's Fair</a> in the United States. Immigrants, mostly Irish and German, settled in Philadelphia and the surrounding districts. The rise in population of the surrounding districts helped lead to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Act_of_Consolidation,_1854&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Act of Consolidation, 1854 (page does not exist)">Act of Consolidation of 1854</a>, which extended the city limits of Philadelphia from the 2 square miles of present-day <a href="/w/index.php?title=Center_City_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Center City (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Center City</a> to the roughly 130 square miles of <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania">Philadelphia County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> These immigrants were largely responsible for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1835_Philadelphia_General_Strike&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1835 Philadelphia General Strike (page does not exist)">first general strike in North America</a> in 1835, in which workers in the city won the ten-hour workday.  The city was a destination for thousands of Irish immigrants fleeing the <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Famine</a> in the 1840s; housing for them was developed south of South Street, and was later occupied by succeeding immigrants. They established a network of Catholic churches and schools, and dominated the Catholic clergy for decades. Anti-Irish, anti-Catholic <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Nativist_Riots" title="Philadelphia Nativist Riots">Nativist riots</a> had erupted in Philadelphia in 1844. In the latter half of the century, immigrants from Russia, Eastern Europe and Italy; and African Americans from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">southern U.S.</a> settled in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Between 1880 and 1930, the African-American population of Philadelphia increased from 31,699 to 219,559.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Twentieth-century black newcomers were part of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a> out of the rural South to northern and midwestern industrial cities.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Union_Club_Philly_Statue_2.jpg" title="File:Union Club Philly Statue 2.jpg">File:Union Club Philly Statue 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Grays_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Grays Monument (page does not exist)">Washington Grays Monument</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Wilson_(sculptor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Wilson (sculptor) (page does not exist)">John A Wilson</a> in front of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Union_League_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Union League of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Union League of Philadelphia</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the American Civil War, Philadelphia was represented by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Grays_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Grays (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Washington Grays (Philadelphia)</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Phila8thMarket.jpg" title="File:Phila8thMarket.jpg">File:Phila8thMarket.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">8th and Market Street, showing the <a href="/wiki/Strawbridge_and_Clothier" title="Strawbridge and Clothier" class="mw-redirect">Strawbridge and Clothier</a> department store, 1910s</div></div></div>
<p>By the 20th century, Philadelphia had become known as "corrupt and contented", with a complacent population and an entrenched <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> <a href="/wiki/Political_machine" title="Political machine">political machine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The first major reform came in 1917 when outrage over the election-year murder of a police officer led to the shrinking of the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Council" title="Philadelphia City Council">Philadelphia City Council</a> from two houses to just one.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> In July 1919, Philadelphia was one of more than 36 industrial cities nationally to suffer a race riot of ethnic whites against blacks during <a href="/wiki/Red_Summer" title="Red Summer" class="mw-redirect">Red Summer</a>, in post-World War I unrest, as recent immigrants competed with blacks for jobs. In the 1920s, the public flouting of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prohibition_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prohibition in the United States (page does not exist)">Prohibition</a> laws, <a href="/wiki/Mafia" title="Mafia">mob</a> violence, and police involvement in illegal activities led to the appointment of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brigadier_General&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brigadier General (page does not exist)">Brigadier General</a> <a href="/wiki/Smedley_Butler" title="Smedley Butler">Smedley Butler</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Marine_Corps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Marine Corps (page does not exist)">U.S. Marine Corps</a> as director of public safety, but political pressure prevented any long-term success in fighting crime and corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1940, non-Hispanic whites constituted 86.8% of the city's population.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> The population peaked at more than two million residents in 1950, then began to decline with the restructuring of industry, which led to the loss of many middle-class union jobs. In addition, suburbanization had been drawing off many of the wealthier residents to outlying railroad commuting towns and newer housing. Revitalization and <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a> of neighborhoods began in the late 1970s and continues into the 21st century, with much of the development in the <a href="/wiki/Center_City,_Philadelphia" title="Center City, Philadelphia">Center City</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_City,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University City, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">University City</a> areas of the city. After many of the old manufacturers and businesses left Philadelphia or shut down, the city started attracting service businesses and began to more aggressively market itself as a tourist destination. Glass-and-granite skyscrapers were built in Center City. Historic areas such as <a href="/wiki/Independence_National_Historical_Park" title="Independence National Historical Park">Independence National Historical Park</a> located in Old City and Society Hill were renovated during the reformist mayoral era of the 1950s through the 1980s.  They are now among the most desirable living areas of Center City. This has slowed the city's 40-year population decline after it lost nearly one-quarter of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The city has attracted more recent immigrants: Hispanics from Central and South America and Asian refugees from Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia.  Educated Asians from India have tended to settle in suburbs with other middle- and upper-class people.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Topography">Topography</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Large_Philadelphia_Landsat.jpg" title="File:Large Philadelphia Landsat.jpg">File:Large Philadelphia Landsat.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A simulated-color image of Philadelphia and the Delaware River, taken by <a href="/w/index.php?title=NASA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NASA (page does not exist)">NASA</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Landsat_7" title="Landsat 7">Landsat 7</a> satellite.</div></div></div>
<p>Philadelphia is at 39° 57′ north latitude and 75° 10′ west longitude, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=40th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="40th parallel north (page does not exist)">40th parallel north</a> passes through the northern parts of the city. The city encompasses <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, of which <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> is land and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, or 5.29%, is water. Bodies of water include the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware</a> and Schuylkill Rivers, and <a href="/wiki/Cobbs_Creek" title="Cobbs Creek">Cobbs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wissahickon_Creek" title="Wissahickon Creek">Wissahickon</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennypack_Creek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennypack Creek (page does not exist)">Pennypack Creeks</a>.
</p><p>The lowest point is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> above sea level, while the highest point is in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chestnut_Hill,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Chestnut Hill</a>, about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Above_mean_sea_level&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Above mean sea level (page does not exist)">above sea level</a> (near the intersection of Germantown Avenue and Bethlehem Pike).<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia sits on the <a href="/wiki/Fall_line" title="Fall line">fall line</a> that separates the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlantic_Coastal_Plain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlantic Coastal Plain (page does not exist)">Atlantic Coastal Plain</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>  The rapids on the Schuylkill River at <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Falls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Falls (page does not exist)">East Falls</a> were inundated by the completion of the Fairmount Dam.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is the seat of <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania">its own county</a>. The adjacent counties are <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Montgomery County, Pennsylvania">Montgomery</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Bucks_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Bucks County, Pennsylvania">Bucks</a> to the northeast; <a href="/wiki/Burlington_County,_New_Jersey" title="Burlington County, New Jersey">Burlington County, New Jersey</a>, to the east; <a href="/wiki/Camden_County,_New_Jersey" title="Camden County, New Jersey">Camden County, New Jersey</a>, to the southeast; <a href="/wiki/Gloucester_County,_New_Jersey" title="Gloucester County, New Jersey">Gloucester County, New Jersey</a>, to the south; and <a href="/wiki/Delaware_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Delaware County, Pennsylvania">Delaware County</a> to the west.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> Philadelphia falls in the northern periphery of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humid_subtropical_climate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humid subtropical climate (page does not exist)">humid subtropical climate</a> zone (Köppen <i>Cfa</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms. The average annual snowfall is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> at an average annual rate of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The most rain ever for one day occurred on July 28, 2013, when   <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> fell at the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_International_Airport" title="Philadelphia International Airport">Philadelphia International Airport</a> as of 9:30 p.m. EDT, according to the <a href="/wiki/National_Weather_Service" title="National Weather Service">National Weather Service</a>.
</p><p>The January daily average is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, though temperatures can lower to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> for a few nights and, conversely, reach <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> somewhat often during winter. July averages <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, although heat waves accompanied by high humidity and <a href="/wiki/Heat_index" title="Heat index">heat indices</a> are frequent; highs reach or exceed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on 27 days of the year. Early fall and late winter are generally driest, with February being the driest month, at an average of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p><p>The snowiest winter has been the 2009–2010 winter season,<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of snow<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The least snowy winter was the 1972–1973 season, with only trace amounts of snowfall.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_American_blizzard_of_1996&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North American blizzard of 1996 (page does not exist)">heaviest single-storm snowfall</a>, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, occurred in January 1996.
</p><p>The highest recorded temperature was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on August 7, 1918, but <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>+ temperatures are uncommon.<sup id="cite_ref-philadelphia1_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-philadelphia1-39">[39]</a></sup> The lowest officially recorded temperature was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on February 9, 1934,<sup id="cite_ref-philadelphia1_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-philadelphia1-39">[39]</a></sup> but temperatures at or below the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> mark are rare.
</p><p><br style="clear:both;" />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Philadelphia_weatherbox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Philadelphia weatherbox (page does not exist)">Template:Philadelphia weatherbox</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Historical_populations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Historical populations (page does not exist)">Template:Historical populations</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable collapsible" style="font-size: 90%;">

<tr>
<th> Racial composition  </th>
<th> 2010<sup id="cite_ref-Gen_Pop.2FHousing_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gen_Pop.2FHousing-40">[40]</a></sup> </th>
<th> 2000<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> </th>
<th> 1990<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> </th>
<th> 1980<sup id="cite_ref-census1990_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census1990-43">[43]</a></sup> </th>
<th> 1970<sup id="cite_ref-census1990_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census1990-43">[43]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>

<td> Native American </td>

</td></tr>

<td> 6.3% </td>
<td> 4.5% </td>
<td> 2.7% </td>
<td rowspan="2"> 1.1% </td>
<td rowspan="2"> 0.3%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Islander_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Islander American (page does not exist)">Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander</a> </td>
<td> 0.0% </td>

</td></tr>

<td> 0.4%
</td></tr>
