<td> 2.8% </td>
<td> 2.2% </td>
<td> n/a<sup id="cite_ref-race_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-race-45">[45]</a></sup> </td>
<td> n/a<sup id="cite_ref-race_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-race-45">[45]</a></sup> </td>
<td> n/a
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanic or Latino</a> (of any race) </td>
<td> 12.3% </td>
<td> 8.5% </td>
<td> 5.6% </td>
<td> 3.8% </td>
<td> 2.4%<sup id="cite_ref-fifteen_44-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fifteen-44">[44]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<p>According to the 2012 United States Census estimates, there were 1,547,67 people residing in the City of Philadelphia. The racial makeup of the city in 2012 was 36.6% Non-Hispanic White, 44.3% Black or African American, 0.8% Native American and Alaska Native, 6.8% Asian, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 2.3% Two or More Races, and 13.0% were Hispanic or Latino.<a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/42/42101.html">[1]</a>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a>, there were 1,526,006 people residing in the City of Philadelphia. This represents a 0.6% increase since the 2000 Census and the first time since the 1950 Census that the city's population showed an increase. The average population density was 11,457 people per square&#160;mile (4,405.4/km²). The 2010 Census Redistricting Data indicated that the racial makeup of the city was 661,839 (43.4%) <a href="/wiki/African_American_(U.S._Census)" title="African American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">African American</a>, 626,221 (41.0%) <a href="/wiki/White_(U.S._Census)" title="White (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">White</a>, 6,996 (0.5%) <a href="/wiki/Native_American_(U.S._Census)" title="Native American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Native American</a>, 96,405 (6.3%) <a href="/wiki/Asian_(U.S._Census)" title="Asian (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Asian</a> (2.0% Chinese, 1.2% Indian, 0.9% Vietnamese, 0.6% Cambodian, 0.4% Korean, 0.3% Filipino, 0.2% Pakistani, 0.1% Indonesian), 744 (0.0%) <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)" title="Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Pacific Islander</a>, 90,731 (5.9%) from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Race_(United_States_Census)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Race (United States Census) (page does not exist)">other races</a>, and 43,070 (2.8%) from two or more races. <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_(U.S._Census)" title="Hispanic (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Hispanic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Latino_(U.S._Census)" title="Latino (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Latino</a> of any race were 187,611 persons (12.3%); 8.0% of Philadelphia is Puerto Rican, 1.0% Dominican, 1.0% Mexican, 0.3% Cuban, and 0.3% Colombian.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> The racial breakdown of Philadelphia's Hispanic/Latino population was 63,636 (33.9%) White, 17,552 (9.4%) African American, 3,498 (1.9%) Native American, 884 (0.47%) Asian, 287 (0.15%) Pacific Islander, 86,626 (46.2%) from other races, and 15,128 (8.1%) from two or more races.<sup id="cite_ref-Gen_Pop.2FHousing_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gen_Pop.2FHousing-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Census reported that 1,468,623 people (96.2% of the population) lived in households, 38,007 (2.5%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 19,376 (1.3%) were institutionalized.<sup id="cite_ref-Gen_Pop.2FHousing_40-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gen_Pop.2FHousing-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were 670,171 housing units, of which 599,736 (89.5%) were occupied and 70,435 (10.5%) were vacant. Of the 599,736 households, 149,193 (24.9%) had children under the age of 18 living with them, 169,587 (28.3%) were married couples living together, 134,648 (22.5%) had a female householder with no husband present, 36,119 (6.0%) had a male householder with no wife present, and 259,382 (43.2%) were non-families. 204,714 (34.1%) of all households were made up of individuals and 62,506 (10.5%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.45 and the average family size was 3.20.<sup id="cite_ref-Gen_Pop.2FHousing_40-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gen_Pop.2FHousing-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population was spread out with 343,837 (22.5%) under the age of 18, 203,697 (13.3%) from 18 to 25, 434,385 (28.5%) from 25 to 44, 358,778 (23.5%) from 45 to 64, and 185,309 (12.1%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 33.5 years. For every 100 females there were 89.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 85.7 males.<sup id="cite_ref-Gen_Pop.2FHousing_40-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gen_Pop.2FHousing-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a>, the top 5 largest ancestries included <a href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">Irish</a> (12.5%), <a href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italian</a> (8.4%), <a href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">German</a> (8.1%), <a href="/wiki/Polish_American" title="Polish American">Polish</a> (3.6%), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English American (page does not exist)">English</a> (3.0%).<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census.gov_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census.gov-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Italians, Irish, Polish, Germans, English, and Greeks are the largest ethnic European groups in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census.gov_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census.gov-48">[48]</a></sup> Philadelphia has the second-largest Italian and Irish populations in the United States, after New York City. <a href="/wiki/South_Philadelphia" title="South Philadelphia">South Philadelphia</a> remains one of the largest Italian neighborhoods in the country and is home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Italian_Market&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Italian Market (page does not exist)">Italian Market</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsport,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsport, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Pennsport</a> neighborhood and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gray%27s_Ferry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gray's Ferry (page does not exist)">Gray's Ferry</a> section of South Philadelphia, home to many <a href="/wiki/Mummers_Parade" title="Mummers Parade">Mummer</a> clubs, are well-known as Irish neighborhoods. The <a href="/wiki/Kensington,_Philadelphia" title="Kensington, Philadelphia">Kensington section</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_Richmond,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port Richmond, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Port Richmond</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fishtown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fishtown (page does not exist)">Fishtown</a> have historically been heavily Irish and Polish. Port Richmond is well-known in particular as the center of the Polish immigrant and Polish-American community in Philadelphia, and it remains a common destination for Polish immigrants. <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast Philadelphia</a>, although known for its Irish and Irish-American population, is also home to a large Jewish and Russian population. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Airy,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Airy, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Mount Airy</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northwest_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northwest Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Northwest Philadelphia</a> also contains a large Jewish community, while nearby <a href="/wiki/Chestnut_Hill,_Philadelphia" title="Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia">Chestnut Hill</a> is historically known as an <a href="/wiki/White_Anglo-Saxon_Protestant" title="White Anglo-Saxon Protestant">Anglo-Saxon Protestant</a> stronghold. 
</p><p>There has also been an increase of  <a href="/wiki/Yuppie" title="Yuppie">yuppie</a>, bohemian, and hipster types particularly around Center City, the neighborhood of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Liberties&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Liberties (page does not exist)">Northern Liberties</a>, and in the neighborhoods around the city's universities, such as near Temple in North Philadelphia and particularly near Drexel and University of Pennsylvania in West Philadelphia.  
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African American</a> population in Philadelphia is the third-largest in the country, after New York City and Chicago. Historically, <a href="/wiki/West_Philadelphia" title="West Philadelphia">West Philadelphia</a> and North Philadelphia were largely black neighborhoods, but many are leaving these areas in favor of the Northeast and Southwest sections of Philadelphia. There is a higher proportion of Muslims in the African American population than most cities in America. West Philadelphia also has significant Caribbean and African populations.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rican_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puerto Rican American (page does not exist)">Puerto Rican</a> population in Philadelphia, is the second-largest after New York City, and the second-fastest growing after Orlando.<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census.gov_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census.gov-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-voxxi.com_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voxxi.com-49">[49]</a></sup> There are large Puerto Rican and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominican_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominican American (page does not exist)">Dominican</a> populations in <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Philadelphia (page does not exist)">North Philadelphia</a> and the Northeast, as well as a significant Mexican population in South Philadelphia.
</p><p>Philadelphia has significant <a href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">Asian</a> populations mainly hailing from countries like India, China, Vietnam, and South Korea. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinatown,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinatown, Philadelphia (page does not exist)"> Chinatown</a> and the Northeast have the largest Asian presences, with a large Korean community in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olney,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olney, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Olney, Philadelphia</a>. South Philadelphia is also home to large Cambodian, Vietnamese, and Chinese communities. 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p>As of 2010, 79.12% (1,112,441) of Philadelphia residents age 5 and older spoke <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">English</a> at home as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Primary_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Primary language (page does not exist)">primary language</a>, while 9.72% (136,688) spoke <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, 1.64% (23,075) <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>, 0.89% (12,499) <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>, 0.77% (10,885) <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, 0.66% (9,240) <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, 0.61% (8,639) <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Asia" title="Languages of Asia">other Asian languages</a>, 0.58% (8,217) <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Africa" title="Languages of Africa">African languages</a>, 0.56% (7,933) <a href="/wiki/Cambodian_language" title="Cambodian language" class="mw-redirect">Cambodian</a> (<a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Mon-Khmer</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a> was spoken as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main language (page does not exist)">main language</a> by 0.55% (7,773) of the population over the age of five. In total, 20.88% (293,544) of Philadelphia's population age 5 and older spoke a <a href="/wiki/Mother_language" title="Mother language" class="mw-redirect">mother language</a> other than English.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Philadelphia's architectural history dates back to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Colonial_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Colonial America (page does not exist)">Colonial</a> times and includes a wide range of styles. The earliest structures were of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Log_home&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Log home (page does not exist)">logs</a> construction, but brick structures were common by 1700. During the 18th century, the <a href="/wiki/Cityscape" title="Cityscape">cityscape</a> was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Georgian_architecture" title="Georgian architecture">Georgian architecture</a>, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independence_Hall_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independence Hall (United States) (page does not exist)">Independence Hall</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christ_Church,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christ Church, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Christ Church</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:OneLiberyPlacePhiladelphia.jpg" title="File:OneLiberyPlacePhiladelphia.jpg">File:OneLiberyPlacePhiladelphia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Center_City_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Center City Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Center City Philadelphia</a> showing <a href="/wiki/One_Liberty_Place" title="One Liberty Place" class="mw-redirect">One Liberty Place</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall" title="Philadelphia City Hall">City Hall</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the first decades of the 19th century, <a href="/wiki/Federal_architecture" title="Federal architecture">Federal architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_Revival_architecture" title="Greek Revival architecture">Greek Revival architecture</a> were dominated by Philadelphia architects such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_Latrobe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin Latrobe (page does not exist)">Benjamin Latrobe</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Strickland_(architect)" title="William Strickland (architect)">William Strickland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Haviland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Haviland (page does not exist)">John Haviland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Notman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Notman (page does not exist)">John Notman</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_U._Walter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas U. Walter (page does not exist)">Thomas U. Walter</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Sloan_(architect)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samuel Sloan (architect) (page does not exist)">Samuel Sloan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Philadelphia-Page251_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philadelphia-Page251-51">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Frank_Furness" title="Frank Furness">Frank Furness</a> is considered Philadelphia's greatest architect of the second half of the 19th century, but his contemporaries included <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_McArthur,_Jr.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John McArthur, Jr. (page does not exist)">John McArthur, Jr.</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Addison_Hutton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Addison Hutton (page does not exist)">Addison Hutton</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilson_Eyre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilson Eyre (page does not exist)">Wilson Eyre</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilson_Brothers_%26_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilson Brothers &amp; Company (page does not exist)">Wilson Brothers</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Horace_Trumbauer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Horace Trumbauer (page does not exist)">Horace Trumbauer</a>. In 1871, construction began on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_Empire_(architecture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second Empire (architecture) (page does not exist)">Second Empire</a>-style <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall" title="Philadelphia City Hall">Philadelphia City Hall</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Historical_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Historical Commission (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Historical Commission</a> was created in 1955 to preserve the cultural and architectural history of the city. The commission maintains the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Register_of_Historic_Places&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Register of Historic Places (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Register of Historic Places</a>, adding historic buildings, structures, sites, objects and districts as it sees fit.<sup id="cite_ref-PNC_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNC-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1932, Philadelphia became home to the first <a href="/wiki/International_Style_(architecture)" title="International Style (architecture)">International Style</a> skyscraper in the United States, The <a href="/w/index.php?title=PSFS_Building&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PSFS Building (page does not exist)">PSFS Building</a>, designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Howe_(architect)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Howe (architect) (page does not exist)">George Howe</a> and <a href="/wiki/William_Lescaze" title="William Lescaze">William Lescaze</a>. It is the United States' first modern skyscraper and considered the most important one built in the first part of the 20th century.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> City Hall remained the tallest building in the city until 1987 when <a href="/wiki/One_Liberty_Place" title="One Liberty Place" class="mw-redirect">One Liberty Place</a> was constructed. Numerous glass and granite skyscrapers were built from the late 1980s onwards. In 2007, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Comcast_Center_(office_building)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Comcast Center (office building) (page does not exist)">Comcast Center</a> surpassed One Liberty Place to become the city's tallest building and make Philadelphia one of only four American cities with two or more buildings over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>; the other cities being <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a>, <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>For much of Philadelphia's history, the typical home has been the <a href="/wiki/Terraced_house" title="Terraced house">row house</a>. The row house was introduced to the United States via Philadelphia in the early 19th century and, for a time, row houses built elsewhere in the United States were known as "Philadelphia rows".<sup id="cite_ref-Philadelphia-Page251_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philadelphia-Page251-51">[51]</a></sup> A variety of row houses are found throughout the city, from Victorian-style homes in North Philadelphia to twin row houses in West Philadelphia. While newer homes are scattered throughout the city, much of the housing is from the early 20th century or older. The great age of the homes has created numerous problems, including blight and vacant lots in many parts of the city, while other neighborhoods such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Society_Hill,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Society Hill, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Society Hill</a>, which has the largest concentration of 18th-century architecture in the United States, have been rehabilitated and gentrified.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The total parkland amounts to about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-parksreport_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parksreport-56">[56]</a></sup> Philadelphia's largest park, <a href="/wiki/Fairmount_Park" title="Fairmount Park">Fairmount Park</a>, encompasses <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of this parkland and includes 63 neighborhood and regional parks.<sup id="cite_ref-fairmonthist_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fairmonthist-57">[57]</a></sup> The largest tract of Fairmount Park is on the west side of the city along the Schuylkill River and <a href="/wiki/Wissahickon_Creek" title="Wissahickon Creek">Wissahickon Creek</a> and includes the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Zoo" title="Philadelphia Zoo">Philadelphia Zoo</a>.
</p><p>The total expenditures of the park in 2005 were $164&#160;million. Fairmount Park is the world's largest landscaped <a href="/w/index.php?title=Urban_park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Urban park (page does not exist)">urban park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Philadelphia_profile_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philadelphia_profile-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Independence_Hall.jpg" title="File:Independence Hall.jpg">File:Independence Hall.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Independence_Hall" title="Independence Hall">Independence Hall</a> in Philadelphia</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Philadelphia is home to many <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Historical_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Historical Park (page does not exist)">national historical sites</a> that relate to the founding of the United States. <a href="/wiki/Independence_National_Historical_Park" title="Independence National Historical Park">Independence National Historical Park</a> is the center of these historical landmarks. <a href="/wiki/Independence_Hall" title="Independence Hall">Independence Hall</a>, where the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a> was signed, and the <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Bell" title="Liberty Bell">Liberty Bell</a> are the city's most famous attractions. Other historic sites include homes for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edgar_Allan_Poe_National_Historic_Site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site (page does not exist)">Edgar Allan Poe</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Betsy_Ross_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betsy Ross House (page does not exist)">Betsy Ross</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thaddeus_Kosciuszko_National_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thaddeus Kosciuszko National Memorial (page does not exist)">Thaddeus Kosciuszko</a>, early government buildings like the <a href="/wiki/First_Bank_of_the_United_States" title="First Bank of the United States">First</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Bank_of_the_United_States" title="Second Bank of the United States">Second Banks of the United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fort_Mifflin" title="Fort Mifflin">Fort Mifflin</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gloria_Dei_(Old_Swedes%27)_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gloria Dei (Old Swedes') Church (page does not exist)">Gloria Dei (Old Swedes') Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia's major science museums include the <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Institute" title="Franklin Institute">Franklin Institute</a>, which contains the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_Franklin_National_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin Franklin National Memorial (page does not exist)">Benjamin Franklin National Memorial</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Natural_Sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy of Natural Sciences (page does not exist)">Academy of Natural Sciences</a>, the <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCtter_Museum" title="Mütter Museum">Mütter Museum</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania_Museum_of_Archaeology_and_Anthropology" title="University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology">University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology</a>. History museums include the <a href="/wiki/National_Constitution_Center" title="National Constitution Center">National Constitution Center</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atwater_Kent_Museum_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atwater Kent Museum of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Atwater Kent Museum of Philadelphia</a> History, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Museum_of_American_Jewish_History&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Museum of American Jewish History (page does not exist)">National Museum of American Jewish History</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_American_Museum_in_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African American Museum in Philadelphia (page does not exist)">African American Museum in Philadelphia</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historical_Society_of_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historical Society of Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Historical Society of Pennsylvania</a>, the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in the state of Pennsylvania and The Masonic Library and Museum of Pennsylvania and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_State_Penitentiary" title="Eastern State Penitentiary">Eastern State Penitentiary</a>. Philadelphia is home to the United States' first <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Zoo" title="Philadelphia Zoo">zoo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Hospital" title="Pennsylvania Hospital">hospital</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Fairmount_Park" title="Fairmount Park">Fairmount Park</a>, one of America's oldest and largest urban parks.
</p><p>The city is home to important archival repositories, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Library_Company_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Library Company of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Library Company of Philadelphia</a>, established in 1731, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Athenaeum_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Athenaeum of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Athenaeum of Philadelphia</a>, founded in 1814. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Presbyterian_Historical_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Presbyterian Historical Society (page does not exist)">Presbyterian Historical Society</a>, the country's oldest continuous denominational historical society, is also located there.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accent">Accent</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_dialect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia dialect (page does not exist)">Philadelphia dialect</a>, though with many unique features, shares many similarities with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_accent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York accent (page does not exist)">New York accent</a>.  Thanks to over a century of linguistics data collected by researchers at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania" title="University of Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a>, the Philadelphia dialect is one of the best-studied forms of American English.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KeysToCommunity.jpg" title="File:KeysToCommunity.jpg">File:KeysToCommunity.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Philadelphia sculptor <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Peniston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Peniston (page does not exist)">James Peniston</a>'s <i>Keys To Community</i> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_City_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old City (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Old City</a> neighborhood is one of the city's <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.philart.net/person.php?id=34">many public artworks</a> featuring <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>. Location: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Coord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Coord (page does not exist)">Template:Coord</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philly042107-014-RockyStatue.jpg" title="File:Philly042107-014-RockyStatue.jpg">File:Philly042107-014-RockyStatue.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Two statues, <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.philart.net/art.php?id=23">The Amazon</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rocky_Steps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rocky Steps (page does not exist)">Rocky</a></i>, outside the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Museum_of_Art" title="Philadelphia Museum of Art">Philadelphia Museum of Art</a></div></div></div>
<p>The city contains many art museums, such as the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Academy_of_the_Fine_Arts" title="Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts">Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rodin_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rodin Museum (page does not exist)">Rodin Museum</a>, which holds the largest collection of work by Auguste Rodin outside of France. The city's major art museum, the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Museum_of_Art" title="Philadelphia Museum of Art">Philadelphia Museum of Art</a>, is one of the largest art museums in the United States. Its long flight of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rocky_Steps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rocky Steps (page does not exist)">steps</a> to the main entrance became famous after the film <i><a href="/wiki/Rocky" title="Rocky">Rocky</a></i> (1976).<sup id="cite_ref-Dallasnews_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dallasnews-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Sketch_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Sketch Club (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Sketch Club</a>, one of the country's oldest artists' clubs, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plastic_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plastic Club (page does not exist)">Plastic Club</a>, started by women excluded from the Sketch Club.  It has a profusion of art galleries, many of which participate in the <a href="/wiki/First_Friday_(public_event)" title="First Friday (public event)">First Friday</a> event. The first Friday of every month, galleries in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_City,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old City, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Old City</a> are open late. Annual events include film festivals and parades, the most famous being the New Year's Day <a href="/wiki/Mummers_Parade" title="Mummers Parade">Mummers Parade</a>.
</p><p>Areas such as South Street and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_City_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old City (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Old City</a> have a vibrant night life. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Avenue_of_the_Arts,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Avenue of the Arts, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Avenue of the Arts</a> in Center City contains many restaurants and theaters, such as the <a href="/wiki/Kimmel_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts">Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts</a>, which is home to the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Orchestra" title="Philadelphia Orchestra">Philadelphia Orchestra</a>, generally considered one of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Five_(orchestras)" title="Big Five (orchestras)">top five orchestras</a> in the United States, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Music_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy of Music (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Academy of Music</a>, the nation's oldest continually operating opera house, home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opera_Company_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opera Company of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Opera Company of Philadelphia</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Ballet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Ballet (page does not exist)">Pennsylvania Ballet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dallasnews_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dallasnews-59">[59]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilma_Theater_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilma Theater (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Wilma Theatre</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Theatre_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Theatre Company (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Theatre Company</a> have new buildings constructed in the last decade on the avenue.  They produce a variety of new works.  Several blocks to the east are the <a href="/wiki/Walnut_Street_Theatre" title="Walnut Street Theatre">Walnut Street Theatre</a>, America’s oldest theatre and the largest subscription theater in the world, as well as the Lantern Theatre at St. Stephens Church, one of a number of smaller venues.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:4th-of-July-1819-Philadelphia-John-Lewis-Krimmel.JPG" title="File:4th-of-July-1819-Philadelphia-John-Lewis-Krimmel.JPG">File:4th-of-July-1819-Philadelphia-John-Lewis-Krimmel.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Fourth of July Celebration in Centre Square, Philadelphia, 1819</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Lewis_Krimmel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Lewis Krimmel (page does not exist)">John Lewis Krimmel</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Philadelphia has more <a href="/wiki/Public_art" title="Public art">public art</a> than any other American city.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> In 1872, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Association_for_Public_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Association for Public Art (page does not exist)">Association for Public Art</a> (formerly the Fairmount Park Art Association) was created, the first private association in the United States dedicated to integrating public art and <a href="/wiki/Urban_planning" title="Urban planning">urban planning</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> In 1959, lobbying by the Artists Equity Association helped create the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Percent_for_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Percent for Art (page does not exist)">Percent for Art</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Law (page does not exist)">ordinance</a>, the first for a U.S. city.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> The program, which has funded more than 200 pieces of public art, is administered by the Philadelphia Office of Arts and Culture, the city's art agency.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia has more murals than any other U.S. city, thanks in part to the 1984 creation of the Department of Recreation's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mural_Arts_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mural Arts Program (page does not exist)">Mural Arts Program</a>, which seeks to beautify neighborhoods and provide an outlet for <a href="/wiki/Graffiti" title="Graffiti">graffiti</a> artists. The program has funded more than 2,800 <a href="/wiki/Mural" title="Mural">murals</a> by professional, staff and volunteer artists and educated more than 20,000 youth in underserved  neighborhoods throughout Philadelphia.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia artists have had a prominent national role in popular <a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">music</a>. In the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_soul" title="Philadelphia soul">Philadelphia soul</a> influenced the music of that and later eras. On July 13, 1985, Philadelphia hosted the American end of the <a href="/wiki/Live_Aid" title="Live Aid">Live Aid</a> concert at <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Stadium" title="John F. Kennedy Stadium">John F. Kennedy Stadium</a>. The city reprised this role for the <a href="/wiki/Live_8" title="Live 8">Live 8</a> concert, bringing some 700,000 people to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ben_Franklin_Parkway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ben Franklin Parkway (page does not exist)">Ben Franklin Parkway</a> on July 2, 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> Philadelphia is home to the world-renowned <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Boys_Choir_%26_Chorale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Boys Choir &amp; Chorale (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Boys Choir &amp; Chorale</a>, which has performed its music all over the world. Dr. Robert G. Hamilton, founder of the choir, is a notable native Philadelphian. The Philly Pops is another famous Philadelphia music group. The city has played a major role in the development and support of American rock music and <a href="/wiki/Rap_music" title="Rap music" class="mw-redirect">rap music</a>. Hip-hop/Rap artists such as <a href="/wiki/The_Roots" title="The Roots">The Roots</a>, <a href="/wiki/DJ_Jazzy_Jeff_%26_The_Fresh_Prince" title="DJ Jazzy Jeff &amp; The Fresh Prince">DJ Jazzy Jeff &amp; The Fresh Prince</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Goats&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Goats (page does not exist)">The Goats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freeway_(rapper)" title="Freeway (rapper)">Freeway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Schoolly_D" title="Schoolly D">Schoolly D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eve_(entertainer)" title="Eve (entertainer)">Eve</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Lopes" title="Lisa Lopes">Lisa "Left Eye" Lopes</a> hail from the city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philly041907-002-PatsKingofSteaks.jpg" title="File:Philly041907-002-PatsKingofSteaks.jpg">File:Philly041907-002-PatsKingofSteaks.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pat's Steaks in South Philadelphia</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The city is known for its <a href="/wiki/Submarine_sandwich" title="Submarine sandwich">hoagies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scrapple" title="Scrapple">scrapple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soft_pretzel" title="Soft pretzel" class="mw-redirect">soft pretzels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_ice" title="Italian ice">water ice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tastykake" title="Tastykake">Tastykake</a>, and is home to the <a href="/wiki/Cheesesteak" title="Cheesesteak">cheesesteak</a>, developed by German and Italian immigrants. Its high-end restaurants include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Le_Bec-Fin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Le Bec-Fin (page does not exist)">Le Bec-Fin</a> and Morimoto, run by chef <a href="/wiki/Masaharu_Morimoto" title="Masaharu Morimoto">Masaharu Morimoto</a>, who rose to prominence on the <i><a href="/wiki/Iron_Chef" title="Iron Chef">Iron Chef</a></i> television show. Italian specialties have been supplemented by many new Vietnamese and other Asian restaurants, both budget and high-end.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Inquirerbldgfull.jpg" title="File:Inquirerbldgfull.jpg">File:Inquirerbldgfull.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Inquirer Building on North Broad Street</div></div></div>
<p>Philadelphia's two major <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newspaper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newspaper (page does not exist)">daily newspapers</a> are <i><a href="/wiki/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer" title="The Philadelphia Inquirer">The Philadelphia Inquirer</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Daily_News" title="Philadelphia Daily News">Philadelphia Daily News</a></i>, both of which are owned by Philadelphia Media Holdings L.L.C. <i>The Philadelphia Inquirer</i>, founded in 1829, is the third-oldest surviving daily newspaper in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Bulletin_(newspaper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Bulletin (newspaper) (page does not exist)">The Bulletin</a></i>, another newspaper that operates in Philadelphia, traces its history back to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Philadelphia_Bulletin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Philadelphia Bulletin (page does not exist)">The Philadelphia Bulletin</a></i> that went defunct in 1982. <i>The Bulletin</i> is locally owned by The Bulletin, Inc.
</p><p>The first experimental radio license was issued in Philadelphia in August 1912 to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_University" title="Saint Joseph's University">St. Joseph's College</a>. The first <a href="/wiki/Commercial_broadcasting" title="Commercial broadcasting">commercial broadcasting</a> radio stations appeared in 1922: first <a href="/w/index.php?title=WIP-AM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WIP-AM (page does not exist)">WIP</a>, then owned by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gimbel%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gimbel's (page does not exist)">Gimbel's department store</a>, on March 17, followed the same year by <a href="/wiki/WFIL" title="WFIL">WFIL</a>, WOO, <a href="/w/index.php?title=WPHT&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WPHT (page does not exist)">WCAU</a> and WDAS.<sup id="cite_ref-Media_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Media-67">[67]</a></sup> The highest-rated stations in Philadelphia include <a href="/wiki/Soft_rock" title="Soft rock">soft rock</a> <a href="/wiki/WBEB" title="WBEB">WBEB</a>, <a href="/wiki/KYW_(AM)" title="KYW (AM)">KYW Newsradio</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Urban_adult_contemporary" title="Urban adult contemporary">urban adult contemporary</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=WDAS-FM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WDAS-FM (page does not exist)">WDAS-FM</a>. Philadelphia is served by three major non-commercial <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">public radio</a> stations, <a href="/wiki/WHYY-FM" title="WHYY-FM">WHYY-FM</a> (NPR), <a href="/wiki/WRTI" title="WRTI">WRTI</a> (jazz, classical), and <a href="/wiki/WXPN-FM" title="WXPN-FM" class="mw-redirect">WXPN-FM</a> (adult alternative music), as well as several smaller stations.
</p><p>In the 1930s, the experimental station <a href="/wiki/KYW-TV" title="KYW-TV">W3XE</a>, owned by <a href="/wiki/Philco" title="Philco">Philco</a>, became the first television station in Philadelphia; it became <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>'s first affiliate in 1939, and later became <a href="/wiki/KYW-TV" title="KYW-TV">KYW-TV</a> (<a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>). <a href="/wiki/WCAU" title="WCAU">WCAU-TV</a>, <a href="/wiki/WPVI-TV" title="WPVI-TV">WPVI-TV</a>, <a href="/wiki/WHYY-TV" title="WHYY-TV">WHYY-TV</a>, <a href="/wiki/WPHL-TV" title="WPHL-TV">WPHL-TV</a>, and <a href="/wiki/WTXF-TV" title="WTXF-TV">WTXF-TV</a> had all been founded by the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-Media_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Media-67">[67]</a></sup> In 1952, WFIL (now WPVI) premiered the television show <i>Bandstand</i>, which later became the nationally broadcast <i><a href="/wiki/American_Bandstand" title="American Bandstand">American Bandstand</a></i> hosted by <a href="/wiki/Dick_Clark" title="Dick Clark">Dick Clark</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Today, as in many large metropolitan areas, each of the commercial networks has an affiliate, and call letters have been replaced by corporate IDs: CBS3, 6ABC, NBC10, Fox29, Telefutura28, Telemundo62, Univision65, plus My PHL 17 and <a href="/w/index.php?title=WPSG-TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WPSG-TV (page does not exist)">CW Philly 57</a>. The region is served also by <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">public broadcasting</a> stations <a href="/w/index.php?title=WYBE-TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WYBE-TV (page does not exist)">WYBE-TV</a> (Philadelphia), WHYY-TV (Wilmington, Delaware and Philadelphia), <a href="/wiki/WLVT-TV" title="WLVT-TV">WLVT-TV</a> (Lehigh Valley), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=NJTV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NJTV (page does not exist)">NJTV</a> (New Jersey). In September 2007, Philadelphia approved a <a href="/wiki/Public-access_television" title="Public-access television">Public-access television</a> cable TV channel.
</p><p>As of 2013, Philadelphia is the only media market in the United States that has <a href="/w/index.php?title=Owned-and-operated_stations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Owned-and-operated stations (page does not exist)">owned-and-operated stations</a> of all five English-language major broadcast networks (NBC – WCAU, CBS – KYW-TV, <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> – WPVI-TV, <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> – WTXF-TV and <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_CW&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The CW (page does not exist)">The CW</a> – WPSG); three of the major Spanish-language networks (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Univision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Univision (page does not exist)">Univision</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=UniMas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UniMas (page does not exist)">UniMas</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Telemundo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Telemundo (page does not exist)">Telemundo</a>) also have O&amp;Os serving the market (respectively, <a href="/wiki/WUVP-DT" title="WUVP-DT">WUVP-DT</a>, <a href="/wiki/WFPA-CA" title="WFPA-CA">WFPA-CA</a> and <a href="/wiki/WWSI" title="WWSI">WWSI</a>).
</p><p>Rock stations <a href="/wiki/WMMR" title="WMMR">WMMR</a> and WYSP had historically been intense rivals. However, in 2011, WYSP switched to sports talk as <a href="/wiki/WIP-FM" title="WIP-FM">WIP-FM</a>, which broadcasts all <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles" title="Philadelphia Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> games. WMMR's <i>The <a href="/wiki/Preston_and_Steve" title="Preston and Steve">Preston and Steve</a> Show</i> has been the area's top-rated morning show since <a href="/wiki/Howard_Stern" title="Howard Stern">Howard Stern</a> left broadcast radio for satellite-based <a href="/wiki/Sirius_Radio" title="Sirius Radio" class="mw-redirect">Sirius Radio</a>.
</p><p>Four <a href="/wiki/Urban_music" title="Urban music" class="mw-redirect">urban</a> stations (<a href="/wiki/WUSL" title="WUSL">WUSL</a> ("Power 99"), <a href="/w/index.php?title=WPHI&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WPHI (page does not exist)">WPHI</a> ("Hot 107.9"), <a href="/w/index.php?title=WDAS-FM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WDAS-FM (page does not exist)">WDAS</a> and <a href="/wiki/WRNB" title="WRNB">WRNB</a> ("Old School 100.3") are popular choices on the FM dial. <a href="/wiki/WBEB" title="WBEB">WBEB</a> is the city's <a href="/wiki/Adult_Contemporary" title="Adult Contemporary" class="mw-redirect">Adult Contemporary</a> station, while <a href="/wiki/WRDW-FM" title="WRDW-FM">WRDW</a> ("Wired 96.5") is the major Rhythmic Top 40 station.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CitizensBankSkyline.JPG" title="File:CitizensBankSkyline.JPG">File:CitizensBankSkyline.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A view of downtown Philadelphia from <a href="/wiki/Citizens_Bank_Park" title="Citizens Bank Park">Citizens Bank Park</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Philadelphia's professional sports teams date at least to the 1860 founding of baseball's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Athletics_(1860-1876)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Athletics (1860-1876) (page does not exist)">Athletics</a>. The city is one of 12 U.S. cities to have <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._cities_with_teams_from_four_major_sports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. cities with teams from four major sports (page does not exist)">all four major sports</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles" title="Philadelphia Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers" title="Philadelphia Flyers">Philadelphia Flyers</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies" title="Philadelphia Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> in the <a href="/wiki/National_League" title="National League">National League</a> of <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers" title="Philadelphia 76ers">Philadelphia 76ers</a> in the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>.
</p><p>The Philadelphia metro area is also home of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Union (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Union</a> of <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>. The Union play their home games at <a href="/w/index.php?title=PPL_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PPL Park (page does not exist)">PPL Park</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Soccer-specific_stadium" title="Soccer-specific stadium">soccer-specific stadium</a> in Chester, Pennsylvania. Philadelphia began play in MLS in 2010, after beating several other cities in competition for the rights to an MLS expansion franchise.
</p><p>The city's professional teams went without a championship from 1983, when the 76ers won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1983_NBA_Finals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1983 NBA Finals (page does not exist)">NBA Championship</a>, until 2008, when the Phillies won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_World_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 World Series (page does not exist)">World Series</a>. In 2004, <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> ranked Philadelphia second on its list of The Fifteen Most Tortured Sports Cities.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> The failure was sometimes attributed in jest to the "<a href="/wiki/Curse_of_Billy_Penn" title="Curse of Billy Penn">Curse of Billy Penn</a>."
</p><p>Major-sport professional sports teams that originated in Philadelphia but ultimately moved to other cities include the <a href="/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors" title="Golden State Warriors">Golden State Warriors</a> basketball team and the <a href="/wiki/Oakland_Athletics" title="Oakland Athletics">Oakland Athletics</a> baseball team.
</p><p>Philadelphia is also the home city of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Spinners&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Spinners (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Spinners</a>, a professional ultimate team that is part of the American Ultimate Disc League. They are one of the original eight teams of the league that began in April 2012 and play their home games at the University of Pennsylvania.
</p><p>Philadelphia is home to professional, semi-professional and elite amateur teams in cricket, rugby league (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Fight&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Fight (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Fight</a>), rugby union and other sports. Major sporting events in the city include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Penn_Relays&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Penn Relays (page does not exist)">Penn Relays</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stotesbury_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stotesbury Cup (page does not exist)">Stotesbury Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Marathon" title="Philadelphia Marathon">Philadelphia Marathon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Broad_Street_Run&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broad Street Run (page does not exist)">Broad Street Run</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_International_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia International Championship (page does not exist)">Philadelphia International Championship</a> <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_racing" title="Bicycle racing">bicycle race</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dad_Vail_Regatta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dad Vail Regatta (page does not exist)">Dad Vail Regatta</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Collegiate_Rugby_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Collegiate Rugby Championship (page does not exist)">Collegiate Rugby Championship</a> is played every June at <a href="/w/index.php?title=PPL_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PPL Park (page does not exist)">PPL Park</a>; the CRC is broadcast live on NBC and regularly draws attendances of 18,000.
</p><p>Philadelphia is home to the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Big_5" title="Philadelphia Big 5">Philadelphia Big 5</a>, a group of five Division I college basketball programs. The Big 5 are <a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_University" title="Saint Joseph's University">Saint Joseph's University</a>, University of Pennsylvania, <a href="/wiki/La_Salle_University" title="La Salle University">La Salle University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Temple_University" title="Temple University">Temple University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Villanova_University" title="Villanova University">Villanova University</a>. The sixth NCAA Division I school in Philadelphia is <a href="/wiki/Drexel_University" title="Drexel University">Drexel University</a>. At least one of the teams is competitive nearly every year<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Vague&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Vague (page does not exist)">Template:Vague</a> and at least one team has made the NCAA tournament for the past four decades<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Which&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Which (page does not exist)">Template:Which</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

</table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Philadelphia is the center of economic activity in <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>. According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, the Philadelphia area had a total gross metropolitan product of $347&#160;billion in 2010, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_United_States_by_GMP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of metropolitan areas in the United States by GMP (page does not exist)">seventh-largest metropolitan economy</a> in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>With a gross domestic product of $388&#160;billion, Philadelphia ranks ninth among world cities and fourth in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> The city is also the nation's fourth-largest consumer <a href="/wiki/Media_market" title="Media market">media market</a>, as ranked by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nielsen_Media_Research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nielsen Media Research (page does not exist)">Nielsen Media Research</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is home to the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Stock_Exchange" title="Philadelphia Stock Exchange">Philadelphia Stock Exchange</a> and several <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies, including cable television and internet provider <a href="/wiki/Comcast" title="Comcast">Comcast</a>, insurance companies <a href="/w/index.php?title=Colonial_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Colonial Penn (page does not exist)">Colonial Penn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=CIGNA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CIGNA (page does not exist)">CIGNA</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Financial_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lincoln Financial Group (page does not exist)">Lincoln Financial Group</a>, energy company <a href="/wiki/Sunoco" title="Sunoco">Sunoco</a>, food services company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aramark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aramark (page does not exist)">Aramark</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crown_Holdings_Incorporated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crown Holdings Incorporated (page does not exist)">Crown Holdings Incorporated</a>, chemical makers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rohm_and_Haas_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rohm and Haas Company (page does not exist)">Rohm and Haas Company</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=FMC_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FMC Corporation (page does not exist)">FMC Corporation</a>, pharmaceutical companies <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wyeth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wyeth (page does not exist)">Wyeth</a> and <a href="/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline" title="GlaxoSmithKline">GlaxoSmithKline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boeing_Rotorcraft_Systems" title="Boeing Rotorcraft Systems">Boeing Rotorcraft Systems</a>, and automotive parts retailer <a href="/wiki/Pep_Boys" title="Pep Boys">Pep Boys</a>.
</p><p>Philadelphia's economic sectors include information technology, manufacturing, oil refining, food processing, health care and biotechnology, tourism and financial services.
</p><p>Philadelphia has shifted to an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Information_technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Information technology (page does not exist)">information technology</a> and service-based economy. Financial activities account for the largest sector of the metro economy, and it is one of the largest health education and research centers in the United States. Philadelphia's history attracts many tourists, with the <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Bell" title="Liberty Bell">Liberty Bell</a> receiving over 2 million visitors in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_government">Law and government</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:City_Hall_holiday.jpg" title="File:City Hall holiday.jpg">File:City Hall holiday.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">City Hall illuminated with projected lights for the 2005 winter holidays</div></div></div>
<p>From a governmental perspective, Philadelphia County is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legal_nullity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legal nullity (page does not exist)">legal nullity</a>, as all county functions were assumed by the city in 1952, which has been coterminous with the county since 1854.
</p><p>Philadelphia's 1952 Home Rule Charter was written by the City Charter Commission, which was created by the Pennsylvania General Assembly in an Act of April 21, 1949, and a city ordinance of June 15, 1949. The existing City Council received a proposed draft on February 14, 1951, and the electors approved it in an election held April 17, 1951.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>  The first elections under the new Home Rule Charter were held in November 1951, and the newly elected officials took office in January 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-Charter_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charter-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city uses the strong-mayor version of the <a href="/wiki/Mayor-council" title="Mayor-council" class="mw-redirect">mayor-council</a> form of government, which is headed by one mayor, in whom executive authority is vested. Elected <a href="/w/index.php?title=At-large&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="At-large (page does not exist)">at-large</a>, the mayor is limited to two consecutive four-year terms under the city's <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">home rule</a> charter, but can run for the position again after an intervening term. The Mayor is <a href="/wiki/Michael_Nutter" title="Michael Nutter">Michael Nutter</a>, who replaced <a href="/wiki/John_F._Street" title="John F. Street">John Street</a>, who served two terms from 1999 to January 2008. Nutter, as all Philadelphia mayors have been since 1952, is a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Democratic_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Democratic Party (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a>, which tends to dominate local politics so thoroughly that the Democratic Mayoral primary is often more widely covered than the general election. The legislative branch, the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Council" title="Philadelphia City Council">Philadelphia City Council</a>, consists of ten council members representing individual districts and seven members elected at large. Democrats currently hold 14 seats, with Republicans representing two allotted at-large seats for the minority party, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast-based</a> Tenth District. The current council president is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Darrell_L._Clarke_(politician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Darrell L. Clarke (politician) (page does not exist)">Darrell Clarke</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Courts">Courts</span></h3>
<p>The Philadelphia County <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Courts_of_Common_Pleas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Courts of Common Pleas (page does not exist)">Court of Common Pleas</a> (First Judicial District) is the <a href="/wiki/Trial_court" title="Trial court">trial court</a> of general jurisdiction for Philadelphia, hearing <a href="/wiki/Felony" title="Felony">felony</a>-level criminal cases and civil suits above the minimum jurisdictional limit of $7000 (excepting small claims cases valued between $7000 and $12000 and landlord-tenant issues heard in the Municipal Court) under its <a href="/wiki/Original_jurisdiction" title="Original jurisdiction">original jurisdiction</a>; it also has <a href="/wiki/Appellate_jurisdiction" title="Appellate jurisdiction">appellate jurisdiction</a> over rulings from the Municipal and Traffic Courts and over decisions of certain Pennsylvania state agencies (e.g. the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Liquor_Control_Board&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board (page does not exist)">Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board</a>). It has 90 legally trained judges elected by the voters. It is funded and operated largely by city resources and employees.<sup id="cite_ref-Common_Pleas_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Common_Pleas-77">[77]</a></sup> The current <a href="/w/index.php?title=District_Attorney_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="District Attorney of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">District Attorney</a> is <a href="/w/index.php?title=R._Seth_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="R. Seth Williams (page does not exist)">Seth Williams</a>, a Democrat. The last Republican to hold the office is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ronald_D._Castille&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ronald D. Castille (page does not exist)">Ron Castille</a>, who left in 1991 and is currently the Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Municipal_Court&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Municipal Court (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Municipal Court</a> handles matters of limited jurisdiction as well as landlord-tenant disputes, appeals from traffic court, preliminary hearings for felony-level offenses, and misdemeanor criminal trials. It has 25 legally trained judges elected by the voters.<sup id="cite_ref-Municipal_Court_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Municipal_Court-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia Traffic Court is a court of special jurisdiction that hears violations of traffic laws. It has seven judges elected by the voters.<sup id="cite_ref-Traffic_Court_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Traffic_Court-79">[79]</a></sup> As with magisterial district judges, the judges need not be lawyers, but must complete the certifying course and pass the qualifying examination administered by the Minor Judiciary Education Board.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pennsylvania's three <a href="/wiki/Appellate_court" title="Appellate court">appellate courts</a> also have sittings in Philadelphia. The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Pennsylvania" title="Supreme Court of Pennsylvania">Supreme Court of Pennsylvania</a>, the court of last resort in the state, regularly hears arguments in <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall" title="Philadelphia City Hall">Philadelphia City Hall</a>. Also, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Superior_Court_of_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Superior Court of Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Superior Court of Pennsylvania</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Court_of_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania</a> sit in Philadelphia several times a year. Judges for these courts are elected at large. Each court has a <a href="/wiki/Prothonotary" title="Prothonotary">prothonotary</a>'s office in Philadelphia as well.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>

</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;"><a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1964" title="United States presidential election, 1964">1964</a>
