<td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">26.2% <i>239,733</i>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;"><b>73.4%</b> <i>670,645</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;"><a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1960" title="United States presidential election, 1960">1960</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">31.8% <i>291,000</i>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;"><b>68.0%</b> <i>622,544</i>
</td></tr></table>
<p>As of December 31, 2009, there were 1,057,038 registered voters in Philadelphia.<sup id="cite_ref-PaDOS_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PaDOS-81">[81]</a></sup> Registered voters constitute 68.3% of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic</a>: 829,873 (78.5%)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a>: 134,216 (12.7%)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Party_(United_States)" title="Libertarian Party (United States)">Libertarian</a> 2,631 (0.2%)
</li>
<li> Other Parties and No party: 90,318 (8.5%)<sup id="cite_ref-PaDOS_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PaDOS-81">[81]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>From the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> until the mid-20th century, Philadelphia was a bastion of the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a>, which arose from the staunch pro-Northern views of Philadelphia residents during and after the war (Philadelphia was chosen as the host city for the first <a href="/wiki/Republican_National_Convention" title="Republican National Convention">Republican National Convention</a> in <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1856" title="United States presidential election, 1856">1856</a>). After the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a>, Democratic registrations increased, but the city was not carried by Democrat <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> in his landslide victory of <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1932" title="United States presidential election, 1932">1932</a> (in which Pennsylvania was one of the few states won by Republican <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Hoover" title="Herbert Hoover">Herbert Hoover</a>). Four years later, however, voter turnout surged and the city finally flipped to the Democrats. Roosevelt carried Philadelphia with over 60% of the vote in <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1936" title="United States presidential election, 1936">1936</a>. The city has remained loyally Democratic in every presidential election since.
</p><p>The city is now one of the most Democratic in the country; in 2008, Democrat <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> drew 83% of the city's vote. Obama's win was even greater in 2012, capturing 85% of the vote.
</p><p>Philadelphia once comprised six <a href="/wiki/Congressional_district" title="Congressional district">congressional districts</a>. However, as a result of the city's declining population, it now has only four: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania%27s_1st_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania's 1st congressional district (page does not exist)">the 1st district</a>, represented by <a href="/wiki/Bob_Brady" title="Bob Brady">Bob Brady</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania%27s_2nd_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania's 2nd congressional district (page does not exist)">the 2nd</a>, represented by <a href="/wiki/Chaka_Fattah" title="Chaka Fattah">Chaka Fattah</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania%27s_8th_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania's 8th congressional district (page does not exist)">the 8th</a>, represented by <a href="/wiki/Mike_Fitzpatrick" title="Mike Fitzpatrick">Mike Fitzpatrick</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania%27s_13th_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania's 13th congressional district (page does not exist)">the 13th</a>, represented by <a href="/wiki/Allyson_Schwartz" title="Allyson Schwartz">Allyson Schwartz</a>. All but Fitzpatrick are Democrats. Although they are usually swamped by Democrats in city, state and national elections, Republicans still have some support in the area; a Republican represented a significant portion of Philadelphia in the House as late as 1983, and <a href="/wiki/Sam_Katz_(Philadelphia)" title="Sam Katz (Philadelphia)">Sam Katz</a> ran competitive Mayoral races as the Republican nominee in both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_mayoral_election,_1999&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia mayoral election, 1999 (page does not exist)">1999</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_mayoral_election,_2003&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia mayoral election, 2003 (page does not exist)">2003</a>. Pennsylvania's longest-serving <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Senators_from_Pennsylvania" title="List of United States Senators from Pennsylvania">Senator</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arlen_Specter" title="Arlen Specter">Arlen Specter</a>, was from Philadelphia; he served as a Republican from 1981 and as a Democrat from 2009, losing that party's primary in <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_Democratic_primary_election_in_Pennsylvania,_2010&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Senate Democratic primary election in Pennsylvania, 2010 (page does not exist)">2010</a> and leaving office in January 2011. He was also the city's District Attorney from 1966 to 1974.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="City_planning">City planning</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Row_Houses,_West_Philly.jpg" title="File:Row Houses, West Philly.jpg">File:Row Houses, West Philly.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Row houses in <a href="/wiki/West_Philadelphia" title="West Philadelphia">West Philadelphia</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Housing_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Housing Authority (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Housing Authority</a> is the largest landlord in Pennsylvania. Established in 1937, it is the nation's fourth-largest housing authority, housing about 84,000 people and employing 1,250. In 2013, its budget was $371&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-PHA_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PHA-84">[84]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Parking_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Parking Authority (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Parking Authority</a> works to ensure adequate parking for city residents, businesses and visitors.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia's neighborhoods are divided into large sections—<a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">North</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northwest_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northwest Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Northwest</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Philadelphia" title="West Philadelphia">West</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Philadelphia" title="South Philadelphia">South</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southwest_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southwest Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Southwest Philadelphia</a>—all of which surround <a href="/wiki/Center_City,_Philadelphia" title="Center City, Philadelphia">Center City</a>, which corresponds closely with the city's limits before consolidation in 1854. Each of these large areas contains numerous neighborhoods, some of whose boundaries derive from the boroughs, townships, and other communities that made up Philadelphia County before their absorption into the city.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crime">Crime</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Like many American cities, Philadelphia saw a gradual yet pronounced rise in crime in the years following World War II. There were 525 murders in 1990, a rate of 31.5 per 100,000. There were an average of about 600 murders a year for most of the 1990s. The murder count dropped in 2002 to 288, then rose four years later to 406 in 2006 and 392 in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> In 2006, Philadelphia's homicide rate of 27.7 per 100,000 people was the highest of the country's 10 most populous cities.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> In 2011, there were 324 murders, a rate of 21.2 per 100,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2004, there were 7,513.5 crimes per 200,000 people in Philadelphia.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In 2005, Philadelphia was ranked by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Morgan_Quitno&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Morgan Quitno (page does not exist)">Morgan Quitno</a> as the sixth-most dangerous among 32 American cities with populations over 500,000.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> Among its neighboring Mid-Atlantic cities in the same population group, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a> and Washington, D.C. were ranked second- and third-most dangerous cities in the United States, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Morgan_Quitno_Rankings_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morgan_Quitno_Rankings-92">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Camden,_New_Jersey" title="Camden, New Jersey">Camden</a>, New Jersey, a city across the Delaware River from Philadelphia, was ranked as the most dangerous city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-Morgan_Quitno_Rankings_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morgan_Quitno_Rankings-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2008, Camden was the second-most dangerous city in the country, while Philadelphia was ranked 22nd.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Penn_campus_2.jpg" title="File:Penn campus 2.jpg">File:Penn campus 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania" title="University of Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a></div></div></div>
<p>Education in Philadelphia is provided by many private and public institutions. The <a href="/wiki/School_District_of_Philadelphia" title="School District of Philadelphia">School District of Philadelphia</a> runs the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_school_(government_funded)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public school (government funded) (page does not exist)">public schools</a>. The Philadelphia School District is the eighth largest <a href="/wiki/School_district" title="School district">school district</a> in the United States with 163,064 students in 347 public and <a href="/wiki/Charter_schools" title="Charter schools" class="mw-redirect">charter schools</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia has the second-largest student concentration on the East Coast, with over 120,000 college and university students enrolled within the city and nearly 300,000 in the metropolitan area. There are over 80 colleges, universities, trade, and specialty schools in the Philadelphia region. The city contains three major research universities: the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania" title="University of Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drexel_University" title="Drexel University">Drexel University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Temple_University" title="Temple University">Temple University</a>; and the city is home to five schools of medicine: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drexel_University_College_of_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drexel University College of Medicine (page does not exist)">Drexel University College of Medicine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_College_of_Osteopathic_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine (page does not exist)">Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temple_University_School_of_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temple University School of Medicine (page does not exist)">Temple University School of Medicine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jefferson_Medical_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jefferson Medical College (page does not exist)">Thomas Jefferson University</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Pennsylvania_School_of_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine (page does not exist)">University of Pennsylvania</a>.
</p><p>Other institutions of higher learning within the city's borders include:
</p>
<table>
<tr>
<td>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_University" title="Saint Joseph's University">Saint Joseph's University</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/La_Salle_University" title="La Salle University">La Salle University</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peirce_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peirce College (page does not exist)">Peirce College</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_the_Sciences_in_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of the Sciences in Philadelphia (page does not exist)">University of the Sciences in Philadelphia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_University_of_the_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The University of the Arts (page does not exist)">The University of the Arts</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" title="Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts" class="mw-redirect">Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Curtis_Institute_of_Music" title="Curtis Institute of Music">Curtis Institute of Music</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson_University" title="Thomas Jefferson University">Thomas Jefferson University</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Moore_College_of_Art_and_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moore College of Art and Design (page does not exist)">Moore College of Art and Design</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_Institute_of_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Art Institute of Philadelphia (page does not exist)">The Art Institute of Philadelphia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Restaurant_School_at_Walnut_Hill_College" title="The Restaurant School at Walnut Hill College">The Restaurant School at Walnut Hill College</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_University" title="Philadelphia University">Philadelphia University</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chestnut_Hill_College" title="Chestnut Hill College">Chestnut Hill College</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Holy_Family_University,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holy Family University, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Holy Family University</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Community_College_of_Philadelphia" title="Community College of Philadelphia">Community College of Philadelphia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Messiah_College" title="Messiah College">Messiah College Philadelphia Campus</a>.
</li>
</ul>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The Philadelphia suburbs are home to a number of other colleges and universities, including <a href="/wiki/Villanova_University" title="Villanova University">Villanova University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bryn_Mawr_College" title="Bryn Mawr College">Bryn Mawr College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haverford_College" title="Haverford College">Haverford College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swarthmore_College" title="Swarthmore College">Swarthmore College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ursinus_College" title="Ursinus College">Ursinus College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabrini_College" title="Cabrini College">Cabrini College</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_University_(United_States)" title="Eastern University (United States)">Eastern University</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philly_30th_St._Station.jpg" title="File:Philly 30th St. Station.jpg">File:Philly 30th St. Station.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">30th Street Station, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cira_Centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cira Centre (page does not exist)">Cira Centre</a> in the background and statues on the Market Street Bridge over <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_River" title="Schuylkill River">Schuylkill River</a> in the foreground</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Philadelphia is served by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (<a href="/wiki/SEPTA" title="SEPTA">SEPTA</a>), which operates buses, trains, rapid transit, trolleys, and trackless trolleys throughout Philadelphia, the four Pennsylvania suburban counties of <a href="/wiki/Bucks_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Bucks County, Pennsylvania">Bucks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chester_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Chester County, Pennsylvania">Chester</a>, <a href="/wiki/Delaware_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Delaware County, Pennsylvania">Delaware</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Montgomery County, Pennsylvania">Montgomery</a>, in addition to service to <a href="/wiki/Mercer_County,_New_Jersey" title="Mercer County, New Jersey">Mercer County, New Jersey</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Castle_County,_Delaware" title="New Castle County, Delaware">New Castle County, Delaware</a>. The city's subway, opened in 1907, is the third-oldest in America.
</p><p>In 1981, large sections of the <a href="/wiki/SEPTA_Regional_Rail" title="SEPTA Regional Rail">SEPTA Regional Rail</a> service to the far suburbs of Philadelphia were discontinued due to lack of funding.  Several projects have been proposed to extend rail service back to these areas, but lack of funding has again been the chief obstacle to implementation.  These projects include the proposed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schuylkill_Valley_Metro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schuylkill Valley Metro (page does not exist)">Schuylkill Valley Metro</a> to Wyomissing, PA and extension of the Media/Elwyn line back to Wawa, PA.
</p><p>SEPTA's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Airport_Line_(SEPTA)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Airport Line (SEPTA) (page does not exist)">Airport Regional Rail Line</a> Regional Rail offers direct service to the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_International_Airport" title="Philadelphia International Airport">Philadelphia International Airport</a>.
</p><p>Philadelphia's <a href="/w/index.php?title=30th_Street_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="30th Street Station (page does not exist)">30th Street Station</a> is a major railroad station on Amtrak's <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a>, which offers access to Amtrak, SEPTA, and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit" title="New Jersey Transit">New Jersey Transit</a> lines.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/PATCO_Speedline" title="PATCO Speedline">PATCO Speedline</a> provides rapid transit service to <a href="/wiki/Camden,_New_Jersey" title="Camden, New Jersey">Camden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collingswood,_New_Jersey" title="Collingswood, New Jersey">Collingswood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Westmont,_New_Jersey" title="Westmont, New Jersey" class="mw-redirect">Westmont</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haddonfield,_New_Jersey" title="Haddonfield, New Jersey">Haddonfield</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cherry_Hill,_New_Jersey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cherry Hill, New Jersey (page does not exist)">Woodcrest (Cherry Hill)</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voorhees,_New_Jersey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voorhees, New Jersey (page does not exist)">Ashland (Voorhees)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lindenwold,_New_Jersey" title="Lindenwold, New Jersey">Lindenwold</a>, New Jersey, from stations on Locust Street between 16th and 15th, 13th and 12th, and 10th and 9th Streets, and on Market Street at 8th Street.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Airports">Airports</span></h3>
<p>Two airports serve Philadelphia: the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_International_Airport" title="Philadelphia International Airport">Philadelphia International Airport</a> (PHL), straddling the southern boundary of the city, and the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia_Airport" title="Northeast Philadelphia Airport">Northeast Philadelphia Airport</a> (PNE), a general aviation reliever airport in <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast Philadelphia</a>. Philadelphia International Airport provides scheduled domestic and international air service, while Northeast Philadelphia Airport serves general and corporate aviation.  In 2010, Philadelphia International Airport was the 12th largest airport in the world <a href="/w/index.php?title=World%27s_busiest_airports_by_traffic_movements&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World's busiest airports by traffic movements (page does not exist)">measured by traffic movements</a> (i.e. takeoffs and landings), and is also a primary hub for <a href="/wiki/US_Airways" title="US Airways">US Airways</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roads">Roads</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philadelphia_Aerial.JPG" title="File:Philadelphia Aerial.JPG">File:Philadelphia Aerial.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Aerial view showing the major highways circumscribing Philadelphia</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Schuylkill_Expressway_Sept_2007.jpg" title="File:Schuylkill Expressway Sept 2007.jpg">File:Schuylkill Expressway Sept 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_Expressway" title="Schuylkill Expressway">Schuylkill Expressway</a>, approaching <a href="/wiki/Center_City,_Philadelphia" title="Center City, Philadelphia">Center City</a> from the north</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_95_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Interstate 95</a> runs through the city along the Delaware River as a main north-south artery known as the Delaware Expressway. The city is also served by the <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_Expressway" title="Schuylkill Expressway">Schuylkill Expressway</a>, a portion of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_76_(east)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 76 (east) (page does not exist)">Interstate 76</a> that runs along the <a href="/wiki/Schuylkill_River" title="Schuylkill River">Schuylkill River</a>. It meets the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Turnpike" title="Pennsylvania Turnpike">Pennsylvania Turnpike</a> at King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, providing access to <a href="/wiki/Harrisburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Harrisburg, Pennsylvania">Harrisburg, Pennsylvania</a> and points west. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_676" title="Interstate 676">Interstate 676</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vine_Street_Expressway" title="Vine Street Expressway" class="mw-redirect">Vine Street Expressway</a>, was completed in 1991 after years of planning. A link between I-95 and I-76, it runs below street level through Center City, connecting to the <a href="/wiki/Ben_Franklin_Bridge" title="Ben Franklin Bridge" class="mw-redirect">Ben Franklin Bridge</a> at its eastern end.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Boulevard_(Philadelphia)" title="Roosevelt Boulevard (Philadelphia)">Roosevelt Boulevard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Expressway_(Philadelphia)" title="Roosevelt Expressway (Philadelphia)" class="mw-redirect">Roosevelt Expressway</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_1_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 1 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">U.S. 1</a>) connect <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast Philadelphia</a> with Center City. Woodhaven Road (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Route_63&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Route 63 (page does not exist)">Route 63</a>), built in 1966, and Cottman Avenue (<a href="/w/index.php?title=PA_Route_73&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PA Route 73 (page does not exist)">Route 73</a>) serve the neighborhoods of <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast Philadelphia</a>, running between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_95_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Interstate 95</a> and the Roosevelt Boulevard (<a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_1_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 1 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">U.S. 1</a>). The Fort Washington Expressway (<a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Route_309" title="Pennsylvania Route 309">Route 309</a>) extends north from the city's northern border, serving <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Montgomery County, Pennsylvania">Montgomery County</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bucks_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Bucks County, Pennsylvania">Bucks County</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_30_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 30 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">U.S. 30</a>, extending east-west from West Philadelphia to <a href="/wiki/Lancaster,_Pennsylvania" title="Lancaster, Pennsylvania">Lancaster</a>, is known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lancaster_Avenue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lancaster Avenue (page does not exist)">Lancaster Avenue</a> throughout most of the city and through the adjacent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Main_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Main Line (page does not exist)">Main Line</a> suburbs.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Interstate_476" title="Interstate 476">Interstate 476</a>, commonly nicknamed the "Blue Route" through <a href="/wiki/Delaware_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Delaware County, Pennsylvania">Delaware County</a>, bypasses the city to the west, serving the city's western suburbs, as well as providing a link to <a href="/wiki/Allentown,_Pennsylvania" title="Allentown, Pennsylvania">Allentown</a> and points north. Similarly, <a href="/wiki/Interstate_276" title="Interstate 276" class="mw-redirect">Interstate 276</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Turnpike" title="Pennsylvania Turnpike">Pennsylvania Turnpike</a>'s Delaware River Extension, acts as a bypass and commuter route to the north of the city as well as a link to the <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Turnpike" title="New Jersey Turnpike">New Jersey Turnpike</a> to New York.
</p><p>However, other planned freeways have been canceled, such as an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_695_(Pennsylvania)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 695 (Pennsylvania) (page does not exist)">Interstate 695</a> running southwest from downtown, two freeways connecting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_95_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Interstate 95</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_76_(east)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 76 (east) (page does not exist)">Interstate 76</a> that would have replaced Girard Avenue and South Street, and a freeway upgrade of <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Boulevard_(Philadelphia)" title="Roosevelt Boulevard (Philadelphia)">Roosevelt Boulevard</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River_Port_Authority" title="Delaware River Port Authority">Delaware River Port Authority</a> operates four bridges in the Philadelphia area across the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware River</a> to <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walt_Whitman_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walt Whitman Bridge (page does not exist)">Walt Whitman Bridge</a> (I-76), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_Franklin_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin Franklin Bridge (page does not exist)">Benjamin Franklin Bridge</a> (I-676 and <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_30_in_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 30 in Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">US 30</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Betsy_Ross_Bridge" title="Betsy Ross Bridge">Betsy Ross Bridge</a> (<a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Route_90" title="New Jersey Route 90">Route 90</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Commodore_Barry_Bridge" title="Commodore Barry Bridge">Commodore Barry Bridge</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Highway_322&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Highway 322 (page does not exist)">US 322</a>). The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tacony-Palmyra_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tacony-Palmyra Bridge (page does not exist)">Tacony-Palmyra Bridge</a> connects <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Route_73&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Route 73 (page does not exist)">PA Route 73</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tacony,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tacony, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">Tacony</a> section of <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Philadelphia" title="Northeast Philadelphia">Northeast Philadelphia</a> with New Jersey's <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Route_73" title="New Jersey Route 73">Route 73</a> in <a href="/wiki/Palmyra,_New_Jersey" title="Palmyra, New Jersey">Palmyra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camden_County,_New_Jersey" title="Camden County, New Jersey">Camden County</a>, and is maintained by the <a href="/wiki/Burlington_County_Bridge_Commission" title="Burlington County Bridge Commission">Burlington County Bridge Commission</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bus_service">Bus service</span></h3>
<p>Philadelphia is also a major hub for <a href="/wiki/Greyhound_Lines" title="Greyhound Lines">Greyhound Lines</a>, which operates 24-hour service to points east of the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">Mississippi River</a>. Most of Greyhound's services in Philadelphia operate to/from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philadelphia_Greyhound_Terminal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philadelphia Greyhound Terminal (page does not exist)">Philadelphia Greyhound Terminal</a>, located at 1001 Filbert Street in Center City Philadelphia. In 2006, the Philadelphia Greyhound Terminal was the second busiest Greyhound terminal in the United States, after the <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a> in New York. Besides Greyhound, six other bus operators provide service to the Center City Greyhound terminal: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bieber_Tourways&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bieber Tourways (page does not exist)">Bieber Tourways</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capitol_Trailways&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capitol Trailways (page does not exist)">Capitol Trailways</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trailways_Transportation_System" title="Trailways Transportation System">Martz Trailways</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_Bus_Lines" title="Peter Pan Bus Lines">Peter Pan Bus Lines</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Susquehanna_Trailways&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Susquehanna Trailways (page does not exist)">Susquehanna Trailways</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Jersey_Transit_Bus_Operations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Jersey Transit Bus Operations (page does not exist)">bus division for New Jersey Transit</a>. Other services include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megabus_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megabus (United States) (page does not exist)">Megabus</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bolt_Bus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bolt Bus (page does not exist)">Bolt Bus</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">Rail</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Suburban_Station_Facade.jpg" title="File:Suburban Station Facade.jpg">File:Suburban Station Facade.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Suburban Station</div></div></div>
<p>Since the early days of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rail_transport_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rail transport in the United States (page does not exist)">rail transport in the United States</a>, Philadelphia has served as hub for several major rail companies, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Railroad" title="Pennsylvania Railroad">Pennsylvania Railroad</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Reading_Railroad" title="Reading Railroad" class="mw-redirect">Reading Railroad</a>. The Pennsylvania Railroad first operated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Broad_Street_Station_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broad Street Station (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Broad Street Station</a>, then <a href="/w/index.php?title=30th_Street_Station_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="30th Street Station (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">30th Street Station</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Suburban_Station_(Philadelphia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suburban Station (Philadelphia) (page does not exist)">Suburban Station</a>, and the Reading Railroad operated out of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reading_Terminal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reading Terminal (page does not exist)">Reading Terminal</a>, now part of the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Convention_Center" title="Pennsylvania Convention Center">Pennsylvania Convention Center</a>. The two companies also operated competing commuter rail systems in the area, known collectively as the Regional Rail system. The two systems today, for the most part still intact but now connected, operate as a single system under the control of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southeastern_Pennsylvania_Transportation_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (page does not exist)">SEPTA</a>, the regional transit authority. Additionally, the <a href="/wiki/PATCO_Speedline" title="PATCO Speedline">PATCO Speedline</a> subway system and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit" title="New Jersey Transit">New Jersey Transit</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_City_Line" title="Atlantic City Line">Atlantic City Line</a> operate successor services to southern <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia, once home to more than 4,000 <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">trolleys</a> on 65 lines,<sup id="cite_ref-route34_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-route34-97">[97]</a></sup> is one of the few North American cities to maintain <a href="/w/index.php?title=Streetcar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Streetcar (page does not exist)">streetcar</a> lines. Today, SEPTA operates five "subway-surface" trolleys that run on street-level tracks in West Philadelphia and subway tunnels in <a href="/wiki/Center_City,_Philadelphia" title="Center City, Philadelphia">Center City</a>. SEPTA also recently<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:When&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:When (page does not exist)">Template:When</a> reintroduced trolley service to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Route_15_(SEPTA)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Route 15 (SEPTA) (page does not exist)">Girard Avenue Line</a>, Route 15.
</p><p>Today, Philadelphia is a regional hub of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government corporation (page does not exist)">federally owned</a> <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> system, with 30th Street Station being a primary stop on the Washington-Boston <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Keystone_Corridor" title="Keystone Corridor">Keystone Corridor</a> to <a href="/wiki/Harrisburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Harrisburg, Pennsylvania">Harrisburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>. 30th Street also serves as a major station for services via the Pennsylvania Railroad's former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_Line_(Pennsylvania_Railroad)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main Line (Pennsylvania Railroad) (page does not exist)">Pennsylvania Main Line</a> to Chicago. 30th Street is Amtrak's third-busiest station in numbers of passengers as of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fiscal_year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fiscal year (page does not exist)">fiscal year</a> 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-busiest_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-busiest-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Walkability">Walkability</span></h3>
<p>A 2011 study by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walk_Score&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walk Score (page does not exist)">Walk Score</a> ranked Philadelphia the fifth most walkable major city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Utilities">Utilities</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philadelphia1.jpg" title="File:Philadelphia1.jpg">File:Philadelphia1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Skyline at night</div></div></div>
<p>Southeastern Pennsylvania was assigned the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Area_code_215&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Area code 215 (page does not exist)">215</a> <a href="/wiki/Area_code" title="Area code" class="mw-redirect">area code</a> in 1947 when the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Numbering_Plan" title="North American Numbering Plan">North American Numbering Plan</a> of the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Bell_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bell System (page does not exist)">Bell System</a>" went into effect. The geographic area covered by the code was split nearly in half in 1994 when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Area_code_610&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Area code 610 (page does not exist)">area code 610</a> was created, with the city and its northern suburbs retaining 215. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Area_code_overlay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Area code overlay (page does not exist)">Overlay area code</a> 267 was added to the 215 service area in 1997, and 484 was added to the 610 area in 1999. A plan in 2001 to introduce a third overlay code to both service areas (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Area_code_445&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Area code 445 (page does not exist)">area code 445</a> to 215, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Area_code_835&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Area code 835 (page does not exist)">area code 835</a> to 610) was delayed and later rescinded.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philadelphia is now also served by Wireless Philadelphia, a citywide initiative to provide <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a> service. The proof of concept area was approved on May 23, 2007, and service is now available in many areas of the city; although discontinued by Earthlink.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States_Postal_Service">United States Postal Service</span></h3>
<p>The main Philadelphia <a href="/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service" title="United States Postal Service">Post Office</a> is at 3000 Chestnut Street in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_City,_Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University City, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (page does not exist)">University City</a> district.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> The facility here became Philadelphia's main post office on September 29, 2008, after the closure of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Post_Office-Main_Branch_(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Post Office-Main Branch (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania) (page does not exist)">former main post office</a> at 30th and Market Streets.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sister_cities">Sister cities</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PhilaChinaArch.jpg" title="File:PhilaChinaArch.jpg">File:PhilaChinaArch.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinatown,_Philadelphia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinatown, Philadelphia (page does not exist)">Chinatown</a> Gate at 10th and Arch, a symbol of Philadelphia's friendship with Tianjin</div></div></div>
<p>Philadelphia has seven official <a href="/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities" title="Twin towns and sister cities">sister cities</a>, as designated by the International Visitors Council of Philadelphia (IVC):<sup id="cite_ref-Diplomacy_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diplomacy-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

<tr>
<th> City
</th>
<th> Country
</th>
<th> Date
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Italy (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Italy</a>
</td>
<td> 1964
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Israel (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Israel</a>
</td>
<td> 1966
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Toru%C5%84" title="Toruń">Toruń</a><sup id="cite_ref-Toru.C5.84_twinnings_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toru.C5.84_twinnings-104">[104]</a></sup>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Poland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Poland (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Poland</a>
</td>
<td> 1976
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">Template:Country data People's Republic of China</a>
</td>
<td> 1980
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Incheon" title="Incheon">Incheon</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_South_Korea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data South Korea (page does not exist)">Template:Country data South Korea</a>
</td>
<td> 1984
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Douala&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Douala (page does not exist)">Douala</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Cameroon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Cameroon (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Cameroon</a>
</td>
<td> 1986
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Russia (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Russia</a>
</td>
<td> 1992
</td></tr></table>
<p>Philadelphia also has three partnership cities or regions:<sup id="cite_ref-Diplomacy_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diplomacy-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

<tr>
<th> City
</th>
<th> Country
</th>
<th> Date
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Kobe" title="Kobe">Kobe</a><sup id="cite_ref-Kobe_sisters_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kobe_sisters-105">[105]</a></sup>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Japan (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Japan</a>
</td>
<td> 1986
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Abruzzo" title="Abruzzo">Abruzzo</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Italy (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Italy</a>
</td>
<td> 1997
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Aix-en-Provence" title="Aix-en-Provence">Aix-en-Provence</a>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data France (page does not exist)">Template:Country data France</a>
</td>
<td> 1999
</td></tr></table>
<p>Philadelphia has dedicated landmarks to its sister cities. Dedicated in June 1976, the Sister Cities Plaza, a site of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> located at 18th and Benjamin Franklin Parkway, honors Philadelphia's relationships with <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a> which were its first sister cities. Another landmark, the Toruń Triangle, honoring the sister city relationship with <a href="/wiki/Toru%C5%84" title="Toruń">Toruń</a>, Poland, was constructed in 1976, west of the <a href="/wiki/United_Way_of_America" title="United Way of America">United Way</a> building at 18th Street and the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. In addition, the Triangle contains the Copernicus monument. Renovations were made to Sister Cities Park in mid-2011 and on May 10, 2012, SCP was reopened and currently features an interactive fountain honoring Philadelphia's ten sister and friendship cities, a café and visitor's center, children's play area, outdoor garden, and boat pond, as well as pavilion built to <a href="/wiki/Environmentally_friendly" title="Environmentally friendly">environmentally friendly</a> standards.<sup id="cite_ref-renovation_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-renovation-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chinatown Gate, erected in 1984 and crafted by artisans of <a href="/wiki/Tianjin,_China" title="Tianjin, China" class="mw-redirect">Tianjin, China</a>, stands astride the intersection of 10th and Arch Streets as an elaborate and colorful symbol of the sister city relationship. The IVC of Philadelphia has participated in the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_State" title="U.S. Department of State" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Department of State</a>'s "Partners for Peace" project with <a href="/wiki/Mosul,_Iraq" title="Mosul, Iraq" class="mw-redirect">Mosul, Iraq</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mosul_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mosul-107">[107]</a></sup> as well as accepting visiting delegations from dozens of other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-ivc_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ivc-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p>

title="Category:Planned cities in the United States (page does not exist)">Planned cities in the United States</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Populated_places_established_in_1682&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Populated places established in 1682 (page does not exist)">Populated places established in 1682</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Populated_places_on_the_Schuylkill_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Populated places on the Schuylkill River (page does not exist)">Populated places on the Schuylkill River</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Port_cities_and_towns_of_the_United_States_Atlantic_coast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Port cities and towns of the United States Atlantic coast (page does not exist)">Port cities and towns of the United States Atlantic coast</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:World_Digital_Library_related&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:World Digital Library related (page does not exist)">World Digital Library related</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Ukrainian_communities_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Ukrainian communities in the United States (page does not exist)">Ukrainian communities in the United States</a></li></ul></div></div>												<div class="visualClear"></div>
							</div>
		</div>
